title: 'I have many things I would like in a mate (for) my children.' If it was (of) rather than (for), would it still make sense? - Quora

response.answer_text: “A mate for my children” sounds natural; “a mate of my children” does not. In the first place, the preposition “for” is used to indicate that something is being done or was done for a future goal or purpose: Have you bought a gift for the newlyweds? We’re looking for a car for my son. I submitted an application for the university. You’d better get some new tires for your bicycle. In all of these sentences, “of” would be incorrect. Secondly, the ‘s construction is usually preferred to the of construction when a person is the possessor. The professor’s exams rather than the exams of the professor My wife’s family rather than the family of my wife So it would sound better to say my children’s mates than the mates of my children. However, since the mates are still theoretical (future), mates for my children is even better. If your children are married, then you can say, for instance, We are very fond of all of our children’s mates (though our children’s spouses or our children’s husbands and wives or our sons and daughters-in-law would all be preferable to “mates,” which is likely to be misunderstood.) Here is another set of examples: I’m looking for a car for my son means that my son does not yet have a car. I’m looking for my son’s car means that he already owns a car; I’m just not sure where it is. I’m looking for the car of my son is unnatural.

Agree w/ Claudia, spot on. The sentence is also lacking clarity. “I have many things” could mean that you personally possess traits that you would like to see in their mates. It also mean that you have many traits in mind, although you may or may not possess them yourself. I suspect you mean the latter. A more clear statement of that would be “There are many things I would like to see in mates for my children.”
